children.name: busy a2
children.definition: busy bận
examples: i’m going to bed. we have a busy day ahead of us tomorrow.
when you are in the police force, the night shift is always busiest.
restaurant managers often employ temporary staff at busy times of the year.

children.name: hectic c1
children.definition: hectic a time or situation that is hectic is extremely busy and you are always rushing and often excited or worried: sôi nổi
examples: it was really hectic at work today.
he’d just returned from a hectic 10 -day trip to new york.
i know you have a hectic schedule, but could you pick something up for me on your way home?

children.name: it’s all go x
children.definition: it’s all go uk spoken used to say that a situation is very busy and full of activity :
examples: it’s all go around here this morning. ten new orders, all marked "urgent'.
it was all go from 8.00 until we finished at 5.00.

children.name: full x
children.definition: fullfull day/morning/week etca day, morning etc in which you have arranged to do a lot of things: bận cả ngày/sáng/tuần
examples: tomorrow will be a very full day. you have several clients to see and two meetings in the afternoon.

children.name: a time when a place is busy
busy a2
children.definition: busy
examples: the morning is our busy time here. it’s quieter in the afternoon.
july is our busiest month, when all the tourists come.

children.name: hectic c1
children.definition: hectic extremely busy, so that you are always in a hurry, and often feel worried or excited: sôi nổi
examples: in the last hectic weeks before the show started we were practically living in the theatre to get it ready on time.
there are two hundred guests arriving in one hour! that’s why things are so hectic!

children.name: the rush c2
children.definition: the rush a very busy time when a lot of people are shopping or travelling: thời điểm nhộn nhịp
examples: buy your tickets early and avoid the rush.
the christmas/summer/weekend etc rush
we’re building up our stocks of books and toys to get ready for the christmas rush.
i try to do my shopping before the christmas rush.

children.name: peak x
children.definition: peak the peak time or period is the time when shops, roads, trains etc are busiest: cao điểm
examples: we usually have two people working in the shop, but at peak periods we employ extra staff.
peak times
extra buses run at peak times .
there should be more buses to cope with the extra passengers at peak times.
a peak time season/ month/ etc
hotel prices rise during the peak season .
in the peak month of july the market sold three hundred tons of melons a day.

children.name: the hustle and bustle x
children.definition: the hustle and bustle when there are a lot of people moving around and doing things, especially in a busy town or city: chen lấn hối hả
examples: the hustle and bustle of
the hustle and bustle of the market place
relax on the beach or enjoy the hustle and bustle of the busy fishing port.
it’s hard to imagine that the park is only a few minutes’ walk from the hustle and bustle of midtown manhattan.

children.name: a time when a place is not busy
quiet a2
children.definition: quiet a quiet day, weekend etc is one in which there is very little business or activity and very few people:
examples: it’s been a very quiet morning so far. only two people came in, and neither of them bought anything.
even on a quiet weekend there are plenty of people on the beach.
this time of the year is always quiet. it gets busy again after winter.

children.name: off-peak x
children.definition: off-peak especially uk the off-peak time, period etc is the time when trains, hotels, tourist areas etc are not busy: ngoài giờ cao điểm
examples: at off-peak times senior citizens can use the sports centre at reduced rates.
take advantage of off-peak reductions for package holidays.
off-peak[adv]
if you can travel off-peak it will be cheaper and the trains will be less crowded.

children.name: quiet a2
children.definition: quiet yên tĩnh, trầm lặng
examples: the house is quiet now that the kids are gone
madison plains, ohio, is a quiet community of 1200 inhabitants.

children.name: sleepy c1
children.definition: sleepy a sleepy place, especially a small town or village, is never busy and very little happens there: yên ắng, im lìm
examples: sticklepath is a sleepy little town right in the heart of the devonshire countryside.
it was a sleepy provincial hotel, not used to having more than two people staying there at any one time.

children.name: buzz c2
children.definition: buzz if a group of people or a place is buzzing, there is a lot of activity or excitement :ồn ào
examples: reporters were buzzingaround, trying to get the full story.
buzz with
the place was buzzing (with excitement).
a classroom buzzing with activity

children.name: busy a1
children.definition: busy a busy place is full of activity or people: nhộn nhịp, đông đúc
examples: even though it was eight o'clock the market was still busy.
paris nowadays is a busy and crowded metropolis
the main road is busy, so be careful when you try to cross it.
this is a very busy area, what with the school, the bus station, and the new shopping mall.
a busy restaurant
their house is near a very busy road.

children.name: lively b1
children.definition: lively a bar, restaurant, club etc that is lively is noisy and full of people who are enjoying themselves: sôi nổi sinh động, náo nhiệt
examples: we got to the disco at about 10 o'clock and it was already quite lively.
it’s the liveliest bar in town, very popular with the tourists.

children.name: bustling x
children.definition: bustling a bustling town, street, area etc is busy and noisy, with a lot of people walking about, going in and out of shops etc: nhộn nhịp bận rộn
examples: the old market is a busy, bustling place, full of local colour.
this used to be a bustling town but a lot of people have moved away over recent years.
bustling with
the house, usually bustling with activity, was strangely silent.

children.name: be in the process of sth c2
children.definition: be in the process of (doing) sth to have started doing sth and not yet be finished:
examples: the company is in the process of moving to new offices.
we're still in the process of decorating the house.

children.name: busy a2
children.definition: busy having a lot of things you should do: bận rộn
examples: she’s very busy -- it’s her daughter’s wedding next week.
angela was becoming more and more unhappy, but her husband was too busy to notice.
not now stephen, i’m busy.
busy doing sth
critics say the mayor is too busy campaigning to do his job properly.
busy with
she was busy with business matters so we decided not to burden her with our problems.
keep sb busy
he’s retired now, but his work for the youth club keeps him busy.
busily[adv]
the chefs were busily preparing hundreds of tantalizing dishes for the banquet.

children.name: be in the middle of sth b1
children.definition: be in the middle of (doing) sth to be busy doing sth : đang mải làm gì
examples: can i call you back – i’m in the middle of a meeting.
i was in the middle of sorting some papers when the phone rang.
someone phoned when i was in the middle of bathing the baby.

children.name: be snowed under c2
children.definition: be snowed under especially uk to be extremely busy and hardly able to deal with all the work you have to do: bận ngập đầu
examples: don’t expect any help from them -- they’re snowed under at the moment.
be snowed under with
since the hurricane, builders and roofers have been snowed under with work.

children.name: have a lot to do a1
children.definition: have a lot to do to have to do a lot of things, and need to hurry or work hard: có nhiều việc phải làm
examples: i’m sorry i can’t talk -- i have a lot to do before my wife gets home.
an awful lot to doused to emphasize you have a lot to do : cả đống việc phải làm
let’s get started. we have an awful lot to do and not much time to do it.

children.name: have a lot on x
children.definition: have a lot onukhave a lot going onus  to be busy, especially because you have arranged to do a lot of things during a short period: còn đống việc
examples: he says he’ll try and see you as soon as possible, but he has a lot going on this afternoon.
we’ve got so much on at work i couldn’t possibly go on holiday now.

children.name: be rushed off your feet x
children.definition: be rushed off your feet /run off your feet especially uk, spoken to be very busy and always in a hurry, because you have a lot of things to do: chạy cuống cuồng
examples: it’s my son’s birthday party tomorrow. i’ve been absolutely rushed off my feet getting ready for it.
all the sales assistants are run off their feet. the shop ought to take on more staff.

children.name: be up to your ears x
children.definition: be up to your ears/neck insth especially spoken to be extremely busy because you have a lot of work to do in your job: chồng chất việc, có cả đống
examples: i’m sorry i can’t talk to you now -- i’m up to my neck in paperwork.
teachers nowadays are up to their ears in administration and don’t have much time for teaching.

children.name: be on the go x
children.definition: on the go spoken to be very busy for a period of time, especially when this makes you tired: chạy đi chạy lại
examples: i’ve been on the go all week -- i’m looking forward to a relaxing weekend now.
she’s always on the go. i don’t know how she does it.

children.name: have your hands full c2
children.definition: have your hands full to be busy because you have to deal with a lot of different jobs or problems, so that you do not have time to do anything else: đầy việc, bận rộn
examples: i’m sorry i can’t help you -- i have my hands full right now
have your hands full with
you must have your hands full with all this work to do and the children to look after.
have your hands full doing sth
the mexican government had its hands full fighting a war on three fronts

children.name: run around c2
children.definition: run aroundinformalto be very busy doing many small jobs : chạy cuống cuồng
examples: i'm exhausted - i've been running around all morning.
maria was running around trying to get the house tidy.
we were allrunning around like headless chickens(= trying to do a lot of things, in an anxious or disorganized way ).

children.name: be not busy a2
children.definition: be not busy rảnh rỗi
examples: let’s find a time when you’re not so busy, and talk about this calmly.
hopefully by march we won’t be so busy.

children.name: not have much to do a1
children.definition: not have much to do especially spoken to not be busy - use this especially to say that you have enough time to do other things: không bận lắm, không có nhiều lắm
examples: i could help if you want -- i don’t have much to do this weekend.
